Section I.—DESCRIPTION OF THE BIBLE 1.

text: Bible. "We believe that the Scriptures of the Old and New Testaments were given by the inspiration of God, and that they only constitute the Divine rule of Christian faith and practice." Section I.—DESCRIPTION OF THE BIBLE 1.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 15
text: "We believe that the Scriptures of the Old and New Testaments were given by the inspiration of God, and that they only constitute the Divine rule of Christian faith and practice." Section I.—DESCRIPTION OF THE BIBLE 1.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 15
text: The Bible is also called "Scripture," "The Scriptures," "The Holy Scriptures." "Scripture" means "writing," the Bible being God's written message to mankind. 3.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 15
text: The Bible is the book upon which The Salvation Army bases both its faith (what it believes) and its practice (what it does). 2.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 15
text: The Bible is the book upon which The Salvation Army bases both its faith (what it believes) and its practice (what it does). 2. The Name of this Book—"Bible"—means "book" or "books." By speaking of it as "The Bible," we mean that it is the book, or the book of books—there is no other like it.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 15
text: The Name of this Book—"Bible"—means "book" or "books." By speaking of it as "The Bible," we mean that it is the book, or the book of books—there is no other like it.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 16
text: This unity of the Bible, in spite of its diversity (differences), points to the fact that one all-controlling Mind must have directed its various human authors. 5.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 16
text: But the Bible has now been translated into at least 550 different languages; in fact, there are comparatively few people in the world who cannot obtain a copy in their own tongue. It is the most widely read and most influential book in existence. 7.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 24
text: II (e) Although each Bible miracle cannot be separately verified, the more important are capable of proof which fully satisfies unprejudiced minds. Take, for example, the evidences for the Resurrection of Jesus Christ, which the enemies of the Bible, in spite of determined efforts, have never been able to disprove. i.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 25
text: THE BIBLE 13 week—our Saturday—but afterwards the Christians observed the first day of the week—our Sunday. This is the origin of the expression "the Lord's Day." vi.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 15
text: The Name of this Book—"Bible"—means "book" or "books." By speaking of it as "The Bible," we mean that it is the book, or the book of books—there is no other like it. The Bible is also called "Scripture," "The Scriptures," "The Holy Scriptures." "Scripture" means "writing," the Bible being God's written message to mankind. 3.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 16
text: Its central theme is Jesus Christ; the Old Testament prepares for Him, the New Testament shows how He fulfilled and exceeded Old Testament expectations. This unity of the Bible, in spite of its diversity (differences), points to the fact that one all-controlling Mind must have directed its various human authors. 5.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 93
text: II.—His Work. Section X.—HIS NATURE I. The Holy Spirit is the Third Person in the Trinity (see Chapter III, Section III). In the Bible the Holy Spirit is also spoken of as "the Spirit of God," "the Spirit of Christ," "the Spirit," "the Comforter," "the Holy Ghost." ("Ghost" is an old English word for "spirit.") 2.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 93

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 56
text: "We believe that our first parents were created in a state of innocence, but by their disobedience they lost their purity and happiness; and that, in consequence of their fall, all men have become sinners, totally depraved, and as such are justly exposed to the wrath of God." Section 1.—THE NATURE OF MAN 1.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 57
text: Man is the Highest Being in Nature. The Bible, human experience and science agree in thus regarding him. Unlike any other creature, he is capable of continual progress, development, education. His superiority is due to the wonderful powers of his soul.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 73
text: I.—The Nature of Sec. III.—The Harmony Redemption. o f RedempII.—The Extent of TION AND Free-will. the Atonement. "We believe that Jesus Christ has, by His suffering and death, made an atonement for the whole world, so that whosoever will may be saved." Section I.—THE NATURE OF REDEMPTION 1.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 73
text: III.—The Harmony Redemption. o f RedempII.—The Extent of TION AND Free-will. the Atonement. "We believe that Jesus Christ has, by His suffering and death, made an atonement for the whole world, so that whosoever will may be saved." Section I.—THE NATURE OF REDEMPTION 1.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 73
text: "We believe that Jesus Christ has, by His suffering and death, made an atonement for the whole world, so that whosoever will may be saved." Section I.—THE NATURE OF REDEMPTION 1.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 51
text: We know that we are forgiven through faith in the merits of Jesus Christ's sacrifice; and we know, too, that this would have been insufficient to atone for sin had He been merely man. Hence we are convinced that He must be God. Section III.—HIS HUMANITY There are many evidences that Jesus Christ was truly man. 1.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 73
text: CHAPTER VI REDEMPTION Sec. I.—The Nature of Sec. III.—The Harmony Redemption. o f RedempII.—The Extent of TION AND Free-will. the Atonement. "We believe that Jesus Christ has, by His suffering and death, made an atonement for the whole world, so that whosoever will may be saved." Section I.—THE NATURE OF REDEMPTION 1.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 102
text: "We believe that repentance towards God, faith in our Lord Jesus Christ, and regeneration by the Holy Spirit are necessary to Salvation. "We believe that we are justified by grace, through faith in our Lord Jesus Christ, and he that believeth hath the witness in himself." Section I.—INTRODUCTORY I.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 102

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 142
text: Section II.—ITS POSSIBILITY 1. We believe that God's People may be delivered from All Sin and enabled to do God's Will continually in This Life. Many people do not agree with this, but maintain that they must go on sinning and repenting

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 122
text: II.—Backsliding. Religion. ! "We believe that the Scriptures teach that not only does continuance in the favor of God depend upon continued faith in, and obedience to, Christ, but that it is possible for those who have been truly converted to fall away and be eternally lost." Section I.—DEVELOPMENT OF RELIGION I.

text: And we believe that persons thus entirely sanctified may, by the power of God, be kept unblamable and unreprovable before Him." Section I.—ITS NATURE I.

"We believe in the immortality of the soul; in the resurrection of the body; in the general judgment at the end of the world; in the eternal happiness of the righteous; and in the everlasting punishment of the wicked/' Section I.—DEATH AND AFTER 1.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 165
text: LAST THINGS 153 Section III.—RESURRECTION 1. Resurrection means the raising to life of dead men's bodies, and reuniting them with their souls. 2.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 172
text: Section V.—HELL 1. Hell is the place or state of final punishment of the wicked; that is, those who die in their sins.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 70
text: 58 HANDBOOK OF DOCTRINE [chap. V the sinner. Being "dead in sin" does not imply unconsciousness or absence of will power; it means that sinners are as powerless to save themselves from the corruption of sin as a corpse is to rescue itself from decay. iii.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 42
text: Section III.—THE UNITY AND TRINITY OF GOD 1. God exists as Trinity in Unity, or Three-inOne. This means that there are Three Persons in the Godhead—the Father, the Son and the Holy Spirit; yet there are not three Gods, hut one God. 2.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 59
text: Therefore, we need not be disturbed by the new theories constantly forthcoming, and we may with confidence accept what the Bible tells us. 2.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 176
text: Section VI.—HEAVEN 1. Heaven is the special abode of God and the angels and the everlasting home of the saved. 2.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 29
text: We cannot, therefore, appeal to His testimony to its inspiration as in the case of the Old Testament. We must find in the New Testament itself its own claim to its inspiration (see (b) iii of this paragraph). (b) The Bible itself claims to be inspired. i.

author: Handbook of Salvation Army Doctrine (1923), p. 29
